Key Arguments: Social media itself is not inherently dangerous; the danger lies in engagement algorithms.
Individuals are capable of deciding what information to trust and agree with.
Algorithms connect people to unfamiliar information sources, bypassing normal social interaction boundaries.
Corporations that benefit from these algorithms should not be trusted to self-regulate.
The government should not approve censorship by entities that do not share national interests.
Main Themes: Government responsibility to protect citizens' interests
Notable Quotes: There is nothing inherently dangerous about social media, and no individual should be prevented from freely expressing themselves to anyone who is willing to listen.
The danger of social media lies in the engagement algorithms that connect people to exotic information whose sources they neither know, nor understand.

Entrusting the same corporations who have the most to gain or lose to self regulate only ensures that their actions will be aligned with their interests - interests indifferent to the welfare and wellbeing of ordinary Australians.
